text: mRNA expression of DNA methyltransferases and methyl-CpG - binding proteins may not be associated with <extra_id_0> IRF-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter methylation

Since abundance of DNMT and MBP contribute to promoter regulation via methylation ( 25 , 26 , 28 ) , we studied their mRNA expression to investigate a possible mechanism for the observed methylation differences in the <extra_id_0> IRF-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .

To this end , we did not detect a significant difference in DNMT ( <extra_id_0> DNMT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> DNMT3A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> DNMT3B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) or MBP ( <extra_id_0> MBD1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> MBD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> MBD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> MeCP <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) mRNA expression between <extra_id_0> IRF-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive and - negative cells ( Figure 5D ) .

text: In fact , all analyzed cells had moderate to high mRNA levels of these tested DNMT / MBPs and differences in expression were not correlated with <extra_id_0> IRF-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> status .

These results indicate a distinct cause of the methylation differences in <extra_id_0> IRF-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive and - negative cells rather than changes in the DNMT and MBP mRNA transcription .
